name: Baptism
description: The foundational sacrament of Christian initiation - the door to life in the Spirit and entry into the Church. Through baptism, a person is incorporated into Christ's death and resurrection, dying to sin and rising to new life, washed clean of all sin and made a member of Christ's Body.
purpose: Forgiveness of all sins (original and personal)
Spiritual rebirth - becoming a new creation in Christ
Incorporation into Christ's death and resurrection
Adoption as a child of God and temple of the Holy Spirit
Entrance into the Church, the Body of Christ
Indelible spiritual marking as belonging to Christ
timing: Administered at any time, but traditionally during Easter Vigil (most fitting as celebrating Christ's resurrection). Infant baptism occurs soon after birth in traditions practicing it. Adult baptism follows period of catechesis.

participants.description: Ordinarily clergy perform baptism, but in emergency any Christian can baptize
Person being baptized - infant or adult believer
Witnesses who promise to support the baptized person's Christian life, especially important for infant baptism
Promise to raise child in Christian faith
Witnesses the baptism and welcomes new member into the Church

steps.details: Candidate (or godparents for infants) renounces Satan and professes faith in the Holy Trinity. Questions: 'Do you renounce Satan and all his works? Do you believe in God the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit?'
Minister prays over the baptismal water, asking God to sanctify it for this sacramental purpose
Water is applied (by immersion, affusion, or aspersion) while minister says: 'I baptize you in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit.'
Forehead anointed with sacred oil signifying the gift of the Holy Spirit and incorporation into Christ (the 'Anointed One')
White garment placed on the baptized, symbolizing putting on Christ and the new creation
Lit candle given (from the Paschal candle), representing Christ the Light and calling to walk as children of light
Congregation welcomes the newly baptized. In some traditions, the person is carried or walks through the church as sign of full membership

tools.purpose: Contains the blessed water for baptism
Essential matter of the sacrament, symbolizing cleansing, death/rebirth, and the Spirit
Symbolizes new life in Christ and purity
Represents Christ as Light of the World
Used to pour water over the head in affusion baptism

forms.symbolism: Most clearly represents burial with Christ (going under water) and resurrection to new life (emerging)
forms.practice: Common practice in early Church, required in Baptist, Orthodox, and some other traditions

forms.description: Water poured over the person's head
forms.symbolism: Represents the outpouring of the Holy Spirit
forms.practice: Widely practiced in Catholic and Protestant churches, became common in medieval period

forms.description: Water sprinkled on the person's head
forms.practice: Least common form but valid in churches that practice it

baptismalFormula.essential: 'I baptize you in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit' - the Trinitarian formula commanded by Christ in Matthew 28:19
baptismalFormula.validity: Both proper water and Trinitarian formula are essential for valid baptism. Baptism in Jesus' name alone (as mentioned in Acts) is considered valid by some denominations but not by others.

infantVsBeliever.practiced: Catholic, Orthodox, Lutheran, Anglican, Reformed churches
infantVsBeliever.theology: God's grace precedes human response. Children of believers should be included in the covenant community, parallel to circumcision in Old Covenant.
infantVsBeliever.biblical: Household baptisms in Acts; parallel between circumcision (given to infants) and baptism
infantVsBeliever.practice: Infant baptized into God's grace; faith will be nurtured as they grow. Confirmation later affirms faith personally.

infantVsBeliever.theology: Baptism should follow personal profession of faith and conscious belief
infantVsBeliever.biblical: New Testament examples show people believed then were baptized
infantVsBeliever.practice: Usually by immersion after person makes public profession of faith. Viewed as testimony of faith already received.

effects: Forgiveness of all sins (original sin and personal sins)
New birth - becomes a new creation in Christ
Justification - declared righteous before God through faith
Sanctification - set apart as holy, dwelling place of the Holy Spirit
Incorporation into Christ's Body, the Church
Adoption as God's child and heir to eternal life
Indelible spiritual mark - baptism cannot be repeated

symbolism.water: Cleansing from sin, death and resurrection, new birth, the Spirit hovering over waters at creation
symbolism.immersion: Burial with Christ in death (going under) and resurrection to new life (rising from water)
symbolism.trinitarian: Invocation of Father, Son, and Holy Spirit reflects Trinitarian nature of God revealed at Jesus' baptism

prayers.title: The Baptismal Formula
prayers.text: I baptize you in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Spirit. Amen.
prayers.context: Essential words spoken while applying water

prayers.title: Renunciation of Satan
prayers.text: Do you renounce Satan and all his works and pomps?

prayers.title: Profession of Faith
prayers.text: Do you believe in God the Father almighty, creator of heaven and earth? Do you believe in Jesus Christ, his only Son, our Lord? Do you believe in the Holy Spirit, the holy catholic Church, the communion of saints, the forgiveness of sins, the resurrection of the body, and life everlasting?
prayers.context: Trinitarian profession using Apostles' Creed structure

biblicalFoundation.significance: Though sinless, Jesus submitted to baptism by John. The heavens opened, the Holy Spirit descended as a dove, and the Father's voice declared 'This is my beloved Son.' This revealed the Trinity and consecrated water for baptism.
biblicalFoundation.quote: And when Jesus was baptized, immediately he went up from the water, and behold, the heavens were opened to him, and he saw the Spirit of God descending like a dove and coming to rest on him; and behold, a voice from heaven said, 'This is my beloved Son, with whom I am well pleased.'

biblicalFoundation.significance: After his resurrection, Jesus commanded the apostles to baptize all nations, establishing baptism as universal means of entry into Christianity
biblicalFoundation.quote: Go therefore and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit

biblicalFoundation.significance: Peter preached and 3,000 were baptized on the day of Pentecost, beginning the Church's practice of baptism
biblicalFoundation.quote: Repent and be baptized every one of you in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins, and you will receive the gift of the Holy Spirit

biblicalFoundation.significance: Jesus told Nicodemus that baptism is necessary for entering the Kingdom
biblicalFoundation.quote: Unless one is born of water and the Spirit, he cannot enter the kingdom of God

primarySources.content: Paul's theology of baptism as participation in Christ's death and resurrection
Early Christian manual describing baptismal practices
'We acknowledge one baptism for the forgiveness of sins'

historicalContext.jewishRoots: Christian baptism emerged from Jewish ritual immersion (mikveh) and John the Baptist's baptism of repentance
historicalContext.earlyChurch: Baptism was immediate response to faith (Acts shows same-day baptisms). Initially by immersion. Adult catechumens prepared for months/years before Easter baptism.
historicalContext.infantBaptism: Evidence for infant baptism appears by 2nd century CE. Became standard practice as Christianity became familial/cultural rather than purely conversion-based.
historicalContext.controversies: Debates over infant vs believer baptism, validity of heretical baptism, rebaptism (forbidden), mode of baptism shaped church history.

modernPractice: Baptism remains universal Christian practice across all denominations, though practices vary (infant vs believer, immersion vs affusion). Baptismal vows are often renewed at Easter. Ecumenical movement has increased mutual recognition of baptisms across denominations.
